feed.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors

entry.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors
entry.summary:
The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) process is currently undergoing scrutiny and suggestions for improvement among members of the Bitcoin development community. There's a consensus on the need to alleviate the workload of current BIP editors by revising the editorial process and considering the addition of new editors. Some community members propose that the role of BIP editors should be limited to ensuring proposals are relevant to the Bitcoin ecosystem and meet minimal formal criteria, arguing that the technical soundness of a BIP should be assessed by the wider community rather than the editors themselves. This approach aims to reduce the burden on editors and expedite the review process.
Further discussions have highlighted the practicalities of modifying existing BIPs and the potential for community members with a good understanding of the BIP process to assist in non-developer triaging. This could involve simple tasks such as identifying missing sections in BIPs, which do not necessarily require developer permissions or in-depth technical knowledge. The suggestion to add more BIP editors has gained traction, with specific candidates being proposed based on their history with Bitcoin development and their ability to objectively evaluate proposals.
Amid these discussions, there are divergent views on whether the BIP repository should remain centralized or if different repositories for BIPs maintained by various parties would be preferable. The debate extends to the selection of new BIP editors, with some advocating for the continuation of the current model where established figures in the community make nominations, while others call for a more democratic approach involving the broader development community.
In conclusion, the conversation around improving the BIP process reflects a broader desire within the Bitcoin community to streamline proposal reviews, reduce backlogs, and enhance the overall efficiency of the development workflow. By potentially expanding the number of editors and refining their roles, the community aims to ensure that the BIP process remains robust, transparent, and conducive to innovation.
